articles.headline: The Rise of Men in Suits. Slim Ones.
articles.snippet: Men’s wear sales are surging at double-digit rates, with suits, sports coats and outerwear, nearly all bought by men themselves, leading the gains.
articles.abstract: Men’s wear sales are surging at double-digit rates, with suits, sports coats and outerwear, nearly all bought by men themselves, leading the gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Men are notoriously averse to shopping. Who can blame them, given the gantlet of women’s fragrances, makeup and handbags that confront them at the entrances to many stores and malls?

articles.headline: A Family Business in Disarray
articles.snippet: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., who has spent his life mediating crises, has no ready remedy for his namesake son, who recently resigned from Congress.
articles.abstract: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., who has spent his life mediating crises, has no ready remedy for his namesake son, who recently resigned from Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO

articles.headline: 30 Years After Chia Pets, Seeds Hit Food Aisles
articles.snippet: With Chia Pets, a mix of seeds and water in an animal-shaped figurine could sprout a plant resembling green hair. Now, chia is becoming a nutritional “it” item.
articles.abstract: With Chia Pets, a mix of seeds and water in an animal-shaped figurine could sprout a plant resembling green hair. Now, chia is becoming a nutritional “it” item.
articles.lead_paragraph: First there were Chia Pets; now there are chia people.

articles.headline: India Unit of Wal-Mart Suspends Employees
articles.snippet: It is the latest setback for the retail giant’s international operations and comes at a sensitive time because India recently allowed foreign retailers to open stores in the country.
articles.abstract: It is the latest setback for the retail giant’s international operations and comes at a sensitive time because India recently allowed foreign retailers to open stores in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Wal-Mart’s Indian joint venture has suspended several senior executives and delayed the opening of some stores in the country as part of an internal bribery investigation, the company said on Friday.

articles.headline: Looking to Industry for the Next Digital Disruption
articles.snippet: General Electric is betting that Internet-era technology is ready to sweep through the industrial economy, much as the consumer Internet has transformed media.
articles.abstract: General Electric is betting that Internet-era technology is ready to sweep through the industrial economy, much as the consumer Internet has transformed media.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN RAMON, Calif. — When Sharoda Paul finished a postdoctoral fellowship last year at the Palo Alto Research Center, she did what most of her peers do — considered a job at a big Silicon Valley company, in her case, Google. But instead, Ms. Paul, a 31-year-old expert in social computing, went to work for General Electric.

articles.headline: Cost-Cutting Cited in Loose Plane Seats
articles.snippet: American Airlines defended its hiring of outside contractors to modify its planes’ cabins, but its unionized mechanics say passengers’ safety was put at risk.
articles.abstract: American Airlines defended its hiring of outside contractors to modify its planes’ cabins, but its unionized mechanics say passengers’ safety was put at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, American Airlines grounded dozens of Boeing 757 airliners after passenger seats came loose on four flights. Just a few weeks earlier, another American plane, a Boeing 767, was grounded after a problem was reported with the installation of some seats, though in that case no seats actually came loose.

articles.headline: Rising Consumer Optimism Fuels an Annual Spree
articles.snippet: Bargain hunters shopped in larger groups and made longer outings Thursday night and Friday at department and discount stores, with analysts predicting strong sales.
articles.abstract: Bargain hunters shopped in larger groups and made longer outings Thursday night and Friday at department and discount stores, with analysts predicting strong sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worries about the economy and fiscal austerity be damned. On Black Friday, consumers were ready to shop till they dropped. And some even did, dozing off on the furniture displays in department stores offering predawn deals.

articles.headline: New Zealand Wants a Hollywood Put on Its Map
articles.snippet: The government of Prime Minister John Key has linked its fortunes to some of Hollywood’s biggest pictures, creating a grand experiment in the fusion of film and government.
articles.abstract: The government of Prime Minister John Key has linked its fortunes to some of Hollywood’s biggest pictures, creating a grand experiment in the fusion of film and government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Standing by his desk in New Zealand’s distinctive round Parliament building, known locally as the Beehive, Prime Minister John Key proudly brandished an ornately engraved sword. It was used, he said, by Frodo Baggins, the protagonist of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy, and in the films it possesses magical powers that cause it to glow blue in the presence of goblins.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Egyptian Judges Challenge Morsi Over New Power
articles.snippet: Judges rebelled against an edict by President Mohamed Morsi exempting his decrees from judicial review, calling for a judges’ strike as protesters took to the streets for a second day.
articles.abstract: Judges rebelled against an edict by President Mohamed Morsi exempting his decrees from judicial review, calling for a judges’ strike as protesters took to the streets for a second day.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian judges rebelled Saturday against an edict by President Mohamed Morsi exempting his decrees from judicial review until ratification of a constitution, denouncing it as a bid for unchecked power and calling for a judges’ strike.

articles.headline: Nintendo Confronts a Changed Video Game World
articles.snippet: Nintendo recently posted a loss as inexpensive, downloadable games for smartphones and tablets have challenged its turf. It is now counterattacking with the Wii U console.
articles.abstract: Nintendo recently posted a loss as inexpensive, downloadable games for smartphones and tablets have challenged its turf. It is now counterattacking with the Wii U console.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.

articles.headline: Hatching Ideas, and Companies, by the Dozens at M.I.T.
articles.snippet: Dr. Robert Langer’s lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is on the front lines of turning discoveries into drugs and drug delivery systems.
articles.abstract: Dr. Robert Langer’s lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is on the front lines of turning discoveries into drugs and drug delivery systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW do you take particles in a test tube, or components in a tiny chip, and turn them into a $100 million company?

articles.headline: Many Moons Later, the I.R.S. Questions a Tax Deal
articles.snippet: Tax experts have long questioned a transaction that resulted in Fairfax Financial, a Canadian insurer, getting a $400 million tax benefit. Years after the fact, the I.R.S. has sided with the skeptics.
articles.abstract: Tax experts have long questioned a transaction that resulted in Fairfax Financial, a Canadian insurer, getting a $400 million tax benefit. Years after the fact, the I.R.S. has sided with the skeptics.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Internal Revenue Service works in mysterious ways. Its wheels grind slowly, but grind they do, as seen in the case of Fairfax Financial Holdings of Toronto.

articles.headline: Election Spurred a Move to Codify U.S. Drone Policy
articles.snippet: An internal debate in Washington concerns when unmanned strikes are justified and whether they should be a last resort or a more flexible tool.
articles.abstract: An internal debate in Washington concerns when unmanned strikes are justified and whether they should be a last resort or a more flexible tool.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing the possibility that President Obama might not win a second term, his administration accelerated work in the weeks before the election to develop explicit rules for the targeted killing of terrorists by unmanned drones, so that a new president would inherit clear standards and procedures, according to two administration officials.

articles.headline: Cold Ravages Syria Refugees as Aid Falters
articles.snippet: Because of a lack of money or access, hundreds of thousands face the onslaught of winter with inadequate shelter, senior government officials and relief organizations said.
articles.abstract: Because of a lack of money or access, hundreds of thousands face the onslaught of winter with inadequate shelter, senior government officials and relief organizations said.
articles.lead_paragraph: MDOUKHA, Lebanon — The winds spilling down off snow-covered Mount Hermon, bearing the first nip of winter, rattled the broken windows of an abandoned elementary school where Syrian refugees are huddled in this Bekaa Valley hamlet.

articles.headline: Lobbying, a Windfall and a Leader’s Family
articles.snippet: The stock holdings of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao’s relatives took a solid jump after Ping An Insurance was granted a waiver to a rule that big financial companies be broken up.
articles.abstract: The stock holdings of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao’s relatives took a solid jump after Ping An Insurance was granted a waiver to a rule that big financial companies be broken up.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — The head of a financially troubled insurer was pushing Chinese officials to relax rules that required breaking up the company in the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis.

articles.headline: For Martha Stewart’s New Fans, Tattoos Meet Appliqué
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart’s focus on artisanal products has attracted a cult following among 20- and 30-somethings who have begun their own businesses around crafts and food.
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart’s focus on artisanal products has attracted a cult following among 20- and 30-somethings who have begun their own businesses around crafts and food.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tony Stinkmetal, a many-tattooed East Village artist and a fixture at the Artists and Fleas craft bazaar in Brooklyn, would not strike most people as a Martha Stewart devotee.

articles.headline: The Senate’s Long Slide to Gridlock
articles.snippet: The Senate — the legislative body designed as the saucer to cool the House’s tempestuous teacup — has become a deep freeze, but filibuster reform could have a thawing effect.
articles.abstract: The Senate — the legislative body designed as the saucer to cool the House’s tempestuous teacup — has become a deep freeze, but filibuster reform could have a thawing effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bob Dole had just assumed the mantle of Senate majority leader, after the Republican landslide of 1994, when he confronted a problem.

articles.headline: Courts Divided Over Searches of Cellphones
articles.snippet: Judges and lawmakers across the country are wrangling over whether and when law enforcement authorities can search suspects’ cellphones without a warrant, and interpretations range widely.
articles.abstract: Judges and lawmakers across the country are wrangling over whether and when law enforcement authorities can search suspects’ cellphones without a warrant, and interpretations range widely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judges and lawmakers across the country are wrangling over whether and when law enforcement authorities can peer into suspects’ cellphones, and the cornucopia of evidence they provide.

articles.headline: Pressure Grows on Egyptian Leader After Judicial Decree
articles.snippet: President Mohamed Morsi defended his decree, but his justice minister urged a retreat following a plunge in the country’s stock market and the threat of more street protests.
articles.abstract: President Mohamed Morsi defended his decree, but his justice minister urged a retreat following a plunge in the country’s stock market and the threat of more street protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Cracks appeared on Sunday in the government of President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt, as he faces mounting pressure over his sweeping decree seeking to elevate his edicts above the reach of any court until a new constitution is approved.

articles.headline: Oprah at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: Trying to bolster her media empire, Oprah Winfrey has been seeking to attract younger audiences to her magazine, which has experienced a decline in advertising revenue since her talk show ended.
articles.abstract: Trying to bolster her media empire, Oprah Winfrey has been seeking to attract younger audiences to her magazine, which has experienced a decline in advertising revenue since her talk show ended.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s not easy to find a fresh way to photograph Oprah Winfrey.

articles.headline: Early Push for Sales Undercuts Black Friday
articles.snippet: Sales on the day after Thanksgiving fell from those a year earlier, after stores started their “doorbuster” promotions early in the week and opened for business on Thursday evening.
articles.abstract: Sales on the day after Thanksgiving fell from those a year earlier, after stores started their “doorbuster” promotions early in the week and opened for business on Thursday evening.
articles.lead_paragraph: After spending years to make Black Friday into the year’s blockbuster shopping day, retailers undercut themselves last week.

articles.headline: Autonomy Founder Challenges H.P.’s Claims
articles.snippet: Autonomy’s founder, Mike Lynch, says he was blindsided by a public relations onslaught from Hewlett-Packard, little of which had to do with the substance of H.P.’s fraud claims about his company.
articles.abstract: Autonomy’s founder, Mike Lynch, says he was blindsided by a public relations onslaught from Hewlett-Packard, little of which had to do with the substance of H.P.’s fraud claims about his company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mike Lynch was growing bored in a business meeting in London on Tuesday when his phone buzzed.

articles.headline: Using War as Cover to Target Journalists
articles.snippet: Journalists who dig into dangerous corners of the world have grown accustomed to being threatened, but now some governments have decided shooting the messenger is a viable option.
articles.abstract: Journalists who dig into dangerous corners of the world have grown accustomed to being threatened, but now some governments have decided shooting the messenger is a viable option.
articles.lead_paragraph: The setting at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel on Tuesday represented the height of refinement, but Alan Rusbridger, editor in chief of The Guardian, reminded the black-tie crowd at the annual dinner for the Committee to Protect Journalists of something it knew all too well: in many parts of the globe, its profession is under murderous assault.

articles.headline: From Man Who Insulted Muhammad, No Regret
articles.snippet: How Nakoula Basseley Nakoula came to make “Innocence of Muslims” is a bizarre tale of fake personas and subterfuge.
articles.abstract: How Nakoula Basseley Nakoula came to make “Innocence of Muslims” is a bizarre tale of fake personas and subterfuge.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Fuming for two months in a jail cell here, Nakoula Basseley Nakoula has had plenty of time to reconsider the wisdom of making “Innocence of Muslims,” his crude YouTube movie trailer depicting the Prophet Muhammad as a bloodthirsty, philandering thug.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: New Breed of SAC Capital Hire Is at Center of Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: Mathew Martoma’s arrest signals the first time that prosecutors have linked Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, to possibly illegal trading activity.
articles.abstract: Mathew Martoma’s arrest signals the first time that prosecutors have linked Steven A. Cohen, the founder of SAC Capital Advisors, to possibly illegal trading activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mathew Martoma walked onto the trading floor at SAC Capital Advisors six years ago, he represented a new breed of employee at the giant hedge fund.

articles.headline: Building Start-Ups via Stars’ Ties to Fans
articles.snippet: Brian Lee, a Web entrepreneur, has been partnering with celebrities like Jessica Alba to create e-commerce sites to sell products in ways that were not possible just a few years ago.
articles.abstract: Brian Lee, a Web entrepreneur, has been partnering with celebrities like Jessica Alba to create e-commerce sites to sell products in ways that were not possible just a few years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: You might have heard Jessica Alba on daytime TV talking about her new e-commerce company, which sells diapers and other baby supplies, or seen Kim Kardashian pitching her online shoe store in the tabloids.

articles.headline: After Dozens of Deaths, Inquiry Into Bed Rails
articles.snippet: Government agencies knew about deaths from strangling on bed rails for years, but did little to address the issue.
articles.abstract: Government agencies knew about deaths from strangling on bed rails for years, but did little to address the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November 2006, when Clara Marshall began suffering from the effects of dementia, her family moved her into the Waterford at Fairway Village, an assisted living home in Vancouver, Wash. The facility offered round-the-clock care for Ms. Marshall, who had wandered away from home several times. Her husband, Dan, 80 years old at the time, felt he could no longer care for her alone.

articles.headline: Congo Slips Into Chaos Again as Rebels Gain
articles.snippet: In the past week, the rebels have been unstoppable, seizing a provincial capital and eviscerating a chaotic Congolese Army.
articles.abstract: In the past week, the rebels have been unstoppable, seizing a provincial capital and eviscerating a chaotic Congolese Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The lights are out in most of Goma. There is little water. The prison is an empty, garbage-strewn wasteland with its rusty front gate swinging wide open and a three-foot hole punched through the back wall, letting loose 1,200 killers, rapists, rogue soldiers and other criminals.

articles.headline: Time Slipping, U.S. Ponders Afghan Role After 2014
articles.snippet: Military planners are drawing up broad outlines of a force that would remain in Afghanistan after 2014, including a small counterterrorism unit with an eye toward Al Qaeda, senior officials said.
articles.abstract: Military planners are drawing up broad outlines of a force that would remain in Afghanistan after 2014, including a small counterterrorism unit with an eye toward Al Qaeda, senior officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and allied military planners are drawing up the broad outlines of a force that would remain in Afghanistan following the handover to Afghan security after 2014, including a small counterterrorism force with an eye toward Al Qaeda, senior officials say.

articles.headline: Rebuilding Wall St.’s Watchdog
articles.snippet: Mary L. Schapiro announced on Monday that she was stepping down as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. She will leave the agency better than she found it.
articles.abstract: Mary L. Schapiro announced on Monday that she was stepping down as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. She will leave the agency better than she found it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary L. Schapiro spent four years at the Securities and Exchange Commission trying to shake the regulator’s past.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Britain Selects a Canadian to Lead the Bank of England
articles.snippet: Mark Carney, a former Goldman Sachs executive who is governor of the Canadian central bank, will replace Mervyn King in July.
articles.abstract: Mark Carney, a former Goldman Sachs executive who is governor of the Canadian central bank, will replace Mervyn King in July.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a surprising departure from convention, the British government on Monday selected Mark J. Carney, the head of the Canadian central bank, to succeed Mervyn A. King as the next governor of the Bank of England.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier
